article-text.p: We are writing to reaffirm our care and support for undocumented members of our community. Your contributions to our campus make UC Santa Cruz a richer and more vibrant place. Our campus is built on a foundation of social justice, and equal access to education and employment is a mainstay of that foundation. Our Principles of Community clearly lay out our commitment: We value the strength that the diversity of our campus community brings to our institution. We believe deeply in equal opportunity.

The University of California system is equally committed to the rights of all students and employees, regardless of immigration status, and it's important that these rights are widely known. Assembly Bill 21 (AB21) was signed into law in 2017 and asks the University of California to provide access to higher education for every student regardless of their immigration status.

UC Santa Cruz is committed to educational access and personal success, and the campus provides an array of support services for our undocumented students, staff and faculty. The campus continues to maintain a designated point of contact and a response team for undergraduate and graduate students, staff and faculty (including academic appointees) who are or may be subject to an immigration order on campus.
Below, we've outlined various scenarios, and what to do in each instance.

ul.li: If you are advised that an immigration officer is expected to enter, will enter, or has entered the campus to execute an immigration order, notify Garrett Naiman, Associate Vice Chancellor for Student Development and Engagement and Dean of Students, as soon as possible. Contact him at 831-502-5009 (available at this number after regular business hours) or via email at deanofstudents@ucsc.edu.

Any student, faculty, or staff who has contact with an immigration officer executing a federal immigration order should refer that individual to our Campus Counsel's Office for purposes of verifying the legality of any warrant, court order, or subpoena. Contact the office at 831-459-1848.

If you are or believe you may be subject to an immigration order or inquiry on campus, Garrett Naiman is again your best contact. Federal and state education privacy laws protect your records, and he is prohibited from disclosing your education information including immigration status to anyone, except as otherwise required by law. Contact him at 831-502-5009 (available at this number after regular business hours) or via email at deanofstudents@ucsc.edu .

article-text.p: For more information about your legal rights in an immigration enforcement situation, we encourage you to contact the UC Immigrant Legal Services Center or visit the Know Your Rights page hosted on the Educational Opportunities Program (EOP) website. You may also refer to the Know Your Rights flyer.
For a complete explanation of UC's policies and procedures relating to undocumented members of our community, as well as for up-to-date immigration information, here are some helpful links:

li.a: UC's Statement in Support of Undocumented Members of the UC Community
Frequently Asked Questions for University Employees about Possible Federal Immigration Enforcement Actions on University Property

article-text.p: It is important to note that federal immigration agencies can and on rare occasions do enter campuses for non-enforcement activities, which can include recruitment events and normal visa processing. The procedures detailed above relate only to enforcement activities.
We recognize that the undocumented members of our community remain vulnerable, and we will continue to support them while advocating for humane comprehensive immigration reform.
If you have any questions about UCSC's implementation of AB21 or anything else you read in this message, you are welcome to email Garrett Naiman at deanofstudents@ucsc.edu.

p.em: Please note: This message is being sent so that all members of the community are informed. We have no indication that Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) has any current plans to come to campus for enforcement activities.

article-text.p:
Sincerely,
Cindy and Lori

Cynthia Larive
Chancellor

Lori Kletzer
Campus Provost and Executive Vice Chancellor
Apoyo a los miembros indocumentados de nuestra comunidad del campus

Les estamos escribiendo para reafirmar nuestra atención y apoyo a los miembros indocumentados de nuestra comunidad. Sus contribuciones a nuestro campus hacen de la UC Santa Cruz un lugar más enriquecido y vibrante. Nuestro campus se ha construido sobre cimientos de justicia social y la igualdad de acceso a la educación y empleo es un pilar de esos cimientos. Nuestros Principios de Comunidad plantean a las claras ese compromiso: Valoramos la fortaleza que trae la diversidad de nuestro campus a nuestra institución. Creemos profundamente en la igualdad de oportunidades.

El sistema de la Universidad de California está comprometido por igual a los derechos de todos sus estudiantes y empleados, sea cual fuere su estatus inmigratorio, y es importante que esos derechos sean ampliamente reconocidos. El Proyecto de Ley de la Asamblea 21 (AB21) se promulgó como ley en 2017 y en él se pide a la Universidad de California dar acceso a la enseñanza superior a todo estudiante sea cual fuere su estatus inmigratorio.

La UC Santa Cruz se compromete a dar acceso educativo y al éxito personal, y su campus proporciona una gama de servicios de apoyo a nuestros estudiantes, personal y facultad indocumentados. El campus continúa brindando un punto de contacto designado y equipo de respuesta a nuestros estudiantes de bachillerato y de posgrado, personal y facultad (inclusive los académicos designados) que estén o pudieran estar sujetos a una orden de inmigración en el campus.
Abajo delineamos varios escenarios, y qué hacer en cada caso.

ul.li: Si a Ud. le advierten que se espera que un oficial de inmigración entre, entrará o ha entrado al campus para aplicar una orden de inmigración, notifique lo antes posible a Garrett Naiman, Vicerrector Asociado de Desarrollo y Enlace Estudiantil y Decano de Estudiantes. Contáctelo al 831-502-5009 (disponible en ese número después de las horas laborables regulares) o vía email al deanofstudents@ucsc.edu.

Cualquier estudiante, miembro de la facultad, o del personal que tenga contacto con un oficial de inmigración que esté aplicando una orden federal de inmigración deberá referir ese individuo a nuestra Oficina de Asesores del Campus a efectos de verificar la legalidad de cualquier orden o citación judicial. Contacte a la oficina, llamando al 831-459-1848.

Si Ud. cree que pudiera estar sujeto a una orden de inmigración o pesquisa en el campus, Garrett Naiman es una vez más su mejor contacto. Las leyes federales y estatales de privacidad en la enseñanza protegen los récords de Ud., y a él le está prohibido divulgar a nadie información acerca de la enseñanza de Ud., incluso estatus inmigratorio, excepto cuando la ley exigiera lo contrario. Contáctelo al 831-502-5009 (disponible en ese número después de las horas laborables regulares) o vía email al deanofstudents@ucsc.edu.

article-text.p: Para más información acerca de sus derechos legales en una situación de aplicación de leyes inmigratorias, lo instamos a contactar el Centro de Servicios Legales Inmigratorios de la UC o visite la Página Know Your Rights patrocinada en el sitio web del Programa de Igualdad de Oportunidades Educativas (EOP, por sus siglas en inglés). Ud. también podrá remitirse al volante Know Your Rights .

Para una explicación completa de las normativas y procedimientos de la UC en relación con los miembros indocumentados de nuestra comunidad, así como información inmigratoria actualizada, he aquí unos enlaces útiles:

li.a: UC's Statement in Support of Undocumented Members of the UC Community
Frequently Asked Questions for University Employees about Possible Federal Immigration Enforcement Actions on University Property

article-text.p: Es importante tener en cuenta que las agencias de inmigración federales pueden entrar, y en algunas ocasiones poco frecuentes entran, a los campus en actividades ajenas a la aplicación de leyes, y esas actividades pudieran ser con fines de reclutamiento o trámites de visado normales. Los procedimientos arriba detallados solo aplican a las actividades de cumplimento de leyes.
Reconocemos la vulnerabilidad de los miembros indocumentados de nuestra comunidad, y queremos continuar apoyándolos a la vez que abogamos por una reforma inmigratoria humana y global.

Si Ud. tuviese algunas preguntas acerca de la implementación de la AB21 en la UCSC o cualquier otra cosa que lea en este mensaje, queda bienvenido a comunicarse por email con Garrett Naiman, al deanofstudents@ucsc.edu.

p.em: Por favor tome nota: Este mensaje se está enviando a fin de informar a todos los miembros de la comunidad. No tenemos ningún indicio de que Aplicación de Inmigración y Aduanas (ICE, por sus siglas en inglés) tenga actualmente planes de venir a nuestro campus para llevar a cabo actividades de aplicación legal.

system-page.title: John D. Pine to serve as Assistant Vice Chancellor for Alumni Engagement
system-page.summary: John D. Pine will lead a team that will build the strategic direction, organizational design, and long-term goals for alumni engagement, collaborating with the Alumni Association, colleagues in University Relations, and partners throughout the campus.

lead-image.image-caption: John D. Pine comes to campus from New York University Abu Dhabi (NYUAD) in the United Arab Emirates, where he is Director of Alumni Relations and Annual Giving.

p.span: UC Santa Cruz has hired John D. Pine as Assistant Vice Chancellor for Alumni Engagement. Pine will lead a team that will build the strategic direction, organizational design, and long-term goals for alumni engagement, collaborating with the Alumni Association, colleagues in University Relations, and partners throughout the campus. Campus aims to provide a dynamic environment in which our 140,000-plus alumni are thoughtfully engaged and stewarded, yielding a life-long relationship with their alma mater, said Mark Delos Reyes Davis, Vice Chancellor for University Relations.

Pine comes to campus from New York University Abu Dhabi (NYUAD) in the United Arab Emirates, where he is Director of Alumni Relations and Annual Giving. There, he established NYU Abu Dhabi’s first comprehensive Alumni Relations and Annual Giving strategic plan. Before that he was Director of Alumni Outreach, Events and Programs at NYU’s Office of Alumni Relations in New York City, and Associate Director of Alumni Relations at the Goizueta Business School of Emory University in Atlanta. He earned his master’s in college student affairs administration from the University of Georgia, and his undergraduate degree in communication from Bridgewater State College in Massachusetts.

“John brings significant experience working with university and alumni leadership, identifying institutional priorities surrounding alumni engagement, and building the infrastructure needed to pursue them,” Davis said.” Everyone with whom he met in the hiring process noted his energy, understanding of and passion for the mission of UC Santa Cruz."
Pine is expected to join campus in February, but will work with UR leadership between now and then to continue to recruit for the Alumni Engagement team.

system-page.title: Priya Mehta to serve as Associate Vice Chancellor for Development
system-page.summary: The Associate Vice Chancellor for Development is a pivotal leadership role on campus, and involves working at the highest levels internally and externally to generate philanthropic support for the university.

image-caption.span: Since 2014, Priya Mehta has served as Assistant Dean, Strategy and External Relations, at UC Berkeley’s School of Public Health.

p.span: UC Santa Cruz has hired Priya Mehta as Associate Vice Chancellor for Development. She is expected to join campus at the start of the new year.

Associate Vice Chancellor for Development is a pivotal leadership role on campus, and involves working at the highest levels internally and externally to generate philanthropic support for the university. Mehta will be responsible for — individually and through the managing of the development team — cultivating long-term donor relationships. She will serve as a principal strategist for leadership and major gifts and oversee Divisional Development staff embedded in the five academic divisions; Planned Giving; and Central Development including regional and campus initiatives. She will also serve as Vice President of the UC Santa Cruz Foundation.

Since 2014, Mehta has served as Assistant Dean, Strategy and External Relations, at UC Berkeley’s School of Public Health. There, she has been responsible for strategic planning and oversight of priority initiatives, as well as advancement, alumni relations, and events. For a number of years she also managed marketing and communications, completing a brand overhaul, full website redesign, and creative campaign for the school's 75th anniversary. The school is currently on track to exceed its $200 million fundraising goal as part of Berkeley’s $6 billion campaign. Previous to that, she was Director of Global Markets for BIO Ventures for Global Health in San Francisco. She earned her master’s in Business Administration from UC Berkeley’s Haas School of Business, and her bachelor’s in Government from Harvard University.
She will succeed Jeff Shilling, who left UC Santa Cruz earlier this fall for another position.

“Throughout the interview process, Priya quickly engendered the respect and trust from the university’s many stakeholders who had the opportunity to meet with her,” said Mark Delos Reyes Davis, Vice Chancellor for University Relations. “She brings with her not only the philanthropic experience needed to successfully serve in this role, but equally important a lens on how philanthropy can move an organization forward. She will be an extraordinary thought-partner to leadership, team members and donors alike as we continue in earnest our planning for our next comprehensive campaign, expected in the next few years."

system-page.title: Graduate student housing town hall
system-page.summary: I continue to work alongside campus leaders to find other sources of support for graduate students, including for summer.

p.span: Dear graduate students,

Thank you for your letters outlining and documenting your struggles in Santa Cruz and at UC Santa Cruz. It saddens me that you feel the university does not care about you, your health or your work. All of us, including the administration, are dedicated to helping graduate students thrive, and we all believe in the transformative effect of higher education. Our campus has experienced the most challenging two years in its history and our region continues to be impacted by the wildfires, the pandemic, and the overarching issue of affordable housing. Amid so much tragedy and continuing challenges, everyone is trying to do their best.
Please believe that I and the rest of the academic leadership are eager to work with you to navigate these difficult times. The $2,500 housing supplement and the

unveiled this year do not solve the underlying problem of a lack of affordable housing in Santa Cruz and on campus. However, I continue to work alongside campus leaders to find other sources of support for graduate students, including for summer.

And I want to work with you and the community to begin to find short and long-term solutions. As a next concrete step, I am organizing a graduate student town hall on housing. The idea is to bring us all together to discuss the issues, look at the data and listen to experts and practitioners to help us explore strategies and options. I’d like to work with you on this and I’m hoping to get suggestions from you, from the Graduate Student Association, and from the Graduate Student Commons to help assemble a panel of campus and community leaders and students, along with experts, to help guide the discussion on this topic.
Please send me any recommendations you have for panelists. I will also strive to ensure that you can submit questions to the panel ahead of time and during the townhall.
I think it’s time to both broaden the discussion surrounding student housing and find new solutions for UCSC.
I look forward to hearing from you and to working together on this with you.
All the best,
Peter Biehl
Vice Provost and Dean of Graduate Studies
